stem: An 8-year-old child is 4 hours post-reduction of a supracondylar humerus fracture. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
SITUATION: The patient is an 8-year-old male who underwent closed reduction and casting of a left supracondylar humerus fracture four hours ago. He is now reporting severe pain and numbness in his left hand.

BACKGROUND: The patient sustained a closed supracondylar humerus fracture during a fall. A long arm cast was applied in the operating room following successful reduction. Pain medication (morphine) was administered 30 minutes ago with minimal relief.

ASSESSMENT: The patient rates his pain as 10/10 and describes it as a deep, aching pain. He states, 'I can't feel my fingers.' Neurovascular assessment reveals a weak radial pulse, delayed capillary refill (5 seconds), pallor, and pain with passive extension of the fingers. Vitals: BP 112/70, HR 128, RR 24.

RECOMMENDATION: I am concerned about acute compartment syndrome (Volkmann's ischemia). I recommend immediate orthopedic evaluation, cast bivalving, and pain management reassessment.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
BP: 112/70 mmHg
HR: 128 bpm (Tachycardia)
RR: 24 breaths/min
SpO2: 98% on room air
Temperature: 37.0°C (98.6°F)

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content:
X-Ray (Post-Reduction):
AP and lateral views of the left elbow demonstrate satisfactory reduction of the supracondylar humerus fracture. No signs of neurovascular compromise are directly visualized on the images.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Morphine: 2 mg IV push administered at 14:30 for pain. No significant pain relief reported.

actionOptions.text: Position the affected arm at the level of the heart
Immediately notify the orthopedic surgeon and bivalve the cast
Elevate the arm above the level of the heart to reduce edema
Apply heat packs to the fingers to promote vasodilation

parameterOptions.text: Continuous neurovascular checks (6 Ps) every 15–30 minutes
Sensation and motor function in the hand/fingers
Daily measurement of serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: The most likely condition is Acute Compartment Syndrome (Volkmann’s Ischemia) (c2). This is supported by the severe pain out of proportion to the injury, pain with passive stretch of the fingers, pallor, and sensory loss. The priority actions are to immediately notify the orthopedic surgeon and bivalve the cast (a2) to relieve pressure and position the affected arm at the level of the heart (a1) to maintain arterial perfusion. Elevating the arm is contraindicated as it can further reduce arterial flow. Continuous neurovascular checks (6 Ps) every 15–30 minutes (p1) and monitoring sensation and motor function in the hand/fingers (p2) are essential to assess for worsening ischemia.
clinicalPearls: Supracondylar humerus fractures are the classic pediatric trigger for Volkmann's ischemia.
Ischemic contracture can occur within 6–12 hours of the blockage, leading to permanent claw-like hands if untreated.
Pain with passive stretch is the most important clinical exam finding for this condition.

questionTrap.trap: Elevating the arm to treat the 'swelling' after a fracture.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While elevation is often used for edema, in the presence of severe pain, pallor, and delayed capillary refill, the priority shifts to maintaining arterial perfusion. Elevation reduces arterial pressure and can worsen ischemia.

mnemonic.title: Volkmann's Warning Signs
mnemonic.expansion: Pain (severe, unrelenting), Pallor (pale skin), Paresthesia (numbness/tingling), Paresis (weakness), Pulselessness (late sign), Pain with passive stretch.
